comment.text: Slowly voltage-gated channel mediating the exchange of chloride ions against protons. Functions as antiporter and contributes to the acidification of the lysosome lumen.
Chloride channel 7 are heteromers of alpha (CLCN7) and beta (OSTM1) subunits.

disease.name: Osteopetrosis, autosomal recessive 4
disease.description: A rare genetic disease characterized by abnormally dense bone, due to defective resorption of immature bone. Osteopetrosis occurs in two forms: a severe autosomal recessive form occurring in utero, infancy, or childhood, and a benign autosomal dominant form occurring in adolescence or adulthood. Recessive osteopetrosis commonly manifests in early infancy with macrocephaly, feeding difficulties, evolving blindness and deafness, bone marrow failure, severe anemia, and hepatosplenomegaly. Deafness and blindness are generally thought to represent effects of pressure on nerves.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.

disease.name: Osteopetrosis, autosomal dominant 2
disease.description: A rare genetic disease characterized by abnormally dense bone, due to defective resorption of immature bone. Osteopetrosis occurs in two forms: a severe autosomal recessive form occurring in utero, infancy, or childhood, and a benign autosomal dominant form occurring in adolescence or adulthood. OPTA2 is the most common form of osteopetrosis, occurring in adolescence or adulthood. It is characterized by sclerosis, predominantly involving the spine, the pelvis and the skull base.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.

disease.name: Osteopetrosis, autosomal recessive 2
disease.description: A rare genetic disease characterized by abnormally dense bone, due to defective resorption of immature bone. Osteopetrosis occurs in two forms: a severe autosomal recessive form occurring in utero, infancy, or childhood, and a benign autosomal dominant form occurring in adolescence or adulthood. Recessive osteopetrosis commonly manifests in early infancy with macrocephaly, feeding difficulties, evolving blindness and deafness, bone marrow failure, severe anemia, and hepatosplenomegaly. Deafness and blindness are generally thought to represent effects of pressure on nerves. OPTB2 is characterized by paucity of osteoclasts, suggesting a molecular defect in osteoclast development.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.

The CLC channel family contains both chloride channels and proton-coupled anion transporters that exchange chloride or another anion for protons. The presence of conserved gating glutamate residues is typical for family members that function as antiporters (By similarity).
Belongs to the chloride channel (TC 2.A.49) family. ClC-7/CLCN7 subfamily.

feature.description: Mediates proton transfer from the outer aqueous phase to the interior of the protein; involved in linking H(+) and Cl(-) transport
Mediates proton transfer from the protein to the inner aqueous phase
In OPTA2 and OPTB4; not detected in the fibroblasts from the patient; dbSNP:rs121434433.
